name: Lingjie Liu
content: Lingjie Liu About Me. I am the Aravind K. Joshi Assistant Professor in the Department of Computer and Information Science at the University of Pennsylvania, where I lead the Penn Computer Graphics Lab and I am also a member of the General Robotics, Automation, Sensing & Perception (GRASP) Lab. Previously, I was a Lise Meitner Postdoctoral Research Fellow at Max Planck Institute for Informatics. I received my Ph.D. degree at the University of Hong Kong in 2019. My research interests are at the interface of Computer Graphics, Computer Vision, and AI, with a focus on Neural Scene Representations, Neural Rendering, Human Performance Modeling and Capture, and 3D Reconstruction. I am especially excited about exploring a new genre of 3D reconstruction and rendering algorithms for human characters and general scenes, which combine classical computer graphics pipelines with deep learning techniques. My long-term vision is to develop AI technologies that can perceive, understand and interact with 3D objects, people, and environments. Specifically, my research will pursue three goals: (1) High-quality 3D reconstruction of real-world scenes from sparse inputs; (2) Efficient and photo-realistic image synthesis of real-world scenes with 3D control; (3) Large-scale 3D scene generation. Prospective Students. There are multiple open research positions in my Lab. Topics of interest include: Neural Representations and Rendering for 3D/4D Reconstruction Physics-Grounded 3D/4D Reconstruction 3D/Video World Simulator Physics-based Human Motion Generation Humanoid Robotics Other topics in Graphics, Vision and Robotics If you are interested in visiting or applying for a research position (e.g., intern, PhD, visiting PhD, or postdoc) in the lab, please fill in the form. We review the form submissions on a biweekly basis. You will be contacted if a fit can be found. Due to the high volume of emails regarding applications, please refrain from emailing me directly. Thank you! [For 2026 PhD Applicants] I am hiring multiple PhD students for 2026. If you’re interested, please apply directly through our Department's application system and list my name as your preferred supervisor (Deadline: December 15, 2025). Due to the high volume of emails regarding applications, I recommend refraining from emailing me directly unless you have a specific question that is not addressed in the application guidelines. We will review all applications from late December 2025 or January 2026, and if you are a good fit for my lab, we will contact you for an interview. Thank you for your interest! Group Members.
